newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuela says ready to settle Japan aluminum spat.
newsitem.headline: Venezuela says ready to settle Japan aluminum spat.

text.p: Venezuelan government officials bound for Japan for talks with minority shareholders in aluminum smelter Venalum said they are willing to negotiate and had no intention of expropriating the Japanese stake.

"The team travels with the best intentions and is open to negotiate without any intention to pressure the Japanese partners with expropriations or other similar actions," Venezuelan Investment Fund (FIV) President Alberto Poletto said in a release.
Poletto, who is responsible for privatizing the Venezuelan aluminum sector which includes Venalum, will head the government team due to arrive in Tokyo on Sunday.
Local press reports had suggested Venezuela might simply expropriate the Japanese consortium's share if it refused to give up its veto power in the 430,000-tonnes-per-year capacity smelter.

The Japanese consortium, which includes Show Denko KK. Kobe Steel Ltd, Sumitomo Chemical Co Ltd, Mitsubishi Materials Corp, Mitsubishi Aluminum Co Ltd and Marubeni Corp, has refused to give up the veto power without compensation.
The Venezuelan government has tried to pressure the Japanese by cutting off its annual shipment of 90,000 tonnes of aluminum.
But with increasing pressure at home to privatize the aluminum sector before the end of the year, Venezuelan officials have shown increasing signs that they are willing to negotiate in recent weeks.
Corporacion Venezolana de Guyana (CVG) President Elias Nadim Ynaty said recently that the government could compensate the Japanese for the loss of veto power.
"Let them name a price and we can negotiate," he said.

And market sources said Thursday that Venalum planned to ship 14,000 tonnes of ingot to the Japanese partners in late August or early September in what would be the first delivery from Venalum for seven months.
